title-group.article-title: Effects of inorganic anions on Fenton oxidation of organic species in landfill leachate

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Earth and Environmental Studies, Montclair State University, Montclair, New Jersey, USA.
2Department of Civil Engineering and Surveying, University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez, Puerto Rico, USA.
3Department of Civil Engineering, Southern Illinois University Carbondale, Carbondale, Illinois, USA.

author-notes.corresp: Yang Deng, Department of Earth and Environmental Studies, Montclair State University, New Jersey 07043, USA Email: ydeng@miami.edu

abstract.p:
Fenton oxidation typically achieves only a moderate removal efficiency of chemical oxidation demand (COD) in treatment of a landfill leachate, incomparable to some other chemical oxidation processes (e.g. electrochemical oxidation). A traditional viewpoint is that the remaining highly oxidized organic species become recalcitrant to hydroxyl radical (OH·)-induced oxidation at a higher degree of Fenton oxidation. Although this may, at least partially, be true, the effects of inorganic anions, which are abundant in leachate, on Fenton oxidation have been largely ignored. The objective of this study is to assess the roles of three inorganic anions (nitrate, sulfate, and chloride) originally present in or externally added to leachate during Fenton oxidation of refractory organic species in leachate. Nitrate
( NO
3
−
)
did not significantly affect the COD removal rate. In contrast, sulfate
(
SO
2
4 −
)
and chloride
( Cl
−
)
, particularly the latter, inhibited Fenton oxidation. Their inhibiting effect may be ascribed to: (1) scavenging of OH·; and (2) competition with H2O2 to form Fe(III) complexes, thus preventing the Fe(II) regeneration from Fe(III) reduction. At 2.125H2O2:initial COD(COD0) = 9.0, [H2O2]:[Fe2+] = 3, and pH = 3.0, 96, 62, 49, and 37% of COD0 (1254 mg L−1) were removed in the presence of 0, 1270, 5000, and 10 000 mg L−1
Cl
−
, respectively.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Landfill leachate is a highly contaminated wastewater produced after precipitation percolates through waste deposited in landfills. As a complicated matrix, it contains high concentrations of organic and inorganic species (Kjeldsen et al., 2002). In particular, dissolved organic matters and xenobiotic organic compounds are two types of undesirable principal contaminants. Uncontrolled leachate discharged directly into the aquatic environment has both acute and chronic impacts on the environment which can severely diminish bio-diversity and greatly reduce populations of sensitive species. Furthermore, public health may be seriously threatened by landfills that are near water sources. Therefore, proper treatment of leachate is critical.

Since the late 1990s, Fenton oxidation has been studied for leachate treatment. In this process, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is added to water with ferrous salt, generating species which are strongly oxidative with respect to organic compounds (Fenton, 1894). Traditionally, hydroxyl radicals (OH·) are regarded as the key oxidizing species (Barb et al., 1951), unselectively degrading most chemical species with rate constants in the order of 107 to 1010 M−1 s−1. The reactions occurring in the Fenton process are listed in Table 1. A typical Fenton oxidation procedure is composed of two sequencing kinetic stages: a rapid Fenton oxidation followed by a much slower Fenton-like reaction. Initially, Fe(II) and H2O2 quickly produce free OH· and Fe (III) (Eq. 4–5). In the subsequent stage, Fe(III) is slowly reduced by H2O2 to regenerate Fe2+ that again reacts with H2O2 to produce additional OH·. Although the Fe(III) reduction was usually expressed as one collective step, it contains two consecutive steps (Pignatello et al., 2007). The first step involves the formation of Fe(III)-peroxide complexes (Eq. 6–7). Graf et al. (1984) found that the occurrence of Fe(III) reduction to Fe(II) required at least one coordination position on Fe(III) open or occupied by a labile ligand. The second step, the rate-limiting one, is the reductive dissociation of the Fe(III)-peroxide complexes to Fe(II) (Eq. 8–9). Once generated, OH· can be scavenged by either of Fenton reagents (Eq. 10–12). Therefore, an optimal molar ratio of Fe(II) to H2O2 can be observed for Fenton treatment of leachate to minimize their scavenging effects (Deng and Englehardt, 2006).

caption.p: Primary reactions occurring in Fenton system in the absence of organic species (data taken from De Laat and Gallard, 1999; Gallard and De Laat, 2000; De Laat and Le, 2005)

sec.p:
Although the Fenton process is anticipated to provide an adequate pre-treatment or full treatment for landfill leachate, it only achieves moderate removal efficiencies in reality. Many studies (Kim et al., 2001; Lau et al., 2002; Englehardt et al., 2006) showed that the ratio of BOD5 to chemical oxidation demand (COD) after Fenton treatment was slightly increased, still below 0.50, implying that it is not an effective pre-treatment technology for biological processes. Furthermore, we recently reviewed 24 experiments and found that the Fenton process only reached an average COD removal of 71% in leachate treatment (Deng, 2009), which was less powerful than electrochemical oxidation that has a typical COD removal of 70 to >90% (Deng and Englehardt, 2007). In electrochemical oxidation, chlorine/hypochlorite, the primary oxidant produced through anoxic oxidation of chloride in leachate, is much less reactive than OH· in the Fenton oxidation. Thus, it is inconceivable that the OH·-based Fenton process is not as effective as electro-oxidation. A traditional viewpoint is that the remaining highly oxidized organic species become recalcitrant to OH·-induced oxidation with the increase in the oxidation degree (Deng and Englehardt, 2006). Although this may, at least partially, be true, the effects of the inorganic anions abundant in leachate on Fenton oxidation may have been largely ignored. These inorganic anions originally exist in or are externally introduced to leachate. Sulfate
( SO
4
2 −
)
and chloride
( Cl
−
)
are commonly found in leachate, with the levels reported at 0–7750 and 0–77 000 mg L−1, respectively (Ehrig, 1989; Reinhart and Grosh, 1998; Kjeldsen et al., 2002; O’Leary and Tchobanoglous, 2002; Ozkaya et al., 2006). Typically,
SO
4
2 −
concentration is expected to decrease with refuse age due to the reduction of sulfate to sulfide with the initiation of anaerobic conditions in the landfill (Kjeldsen et al., 2002; Ozkaya et al., 2006). Chloride is a non-biodegradable conservative species, and its change is generally used to assess the variation in leachate dilution (Ozkaya et al., 2006). Alternatively, nitrate, sulfate and chloride may be introduced from the acids used for pH adjustment and ferrous salts in Fenton treatment. Their quantities depend on leachate alkalinity and doses of Fenton reagents. For example, if HNO3, H2SO4, or HCl is used to adjust pH to 3.0 for a leachate with an alkalinity of 3000 mg L−1 CaCO3, a typical data reported by O’Leary and Tchobanoglous (2002), approximately 3720 mg L−1
( NO
3
−
)
, 5760 mg L−1
SO
4
2 −
, or 2130 mg L−1
Cl
−
will be introduced correspondingly. The objective of this study is to investigate effects of various inorganic anions probably largely present in leachate on Fenton oxidation of leachate.

sec.title: Material and methods
sec.p:
Landfill leachate was collected from the Cabo Rojo Landfill (Cabo Rojo, Puerto Rico, USA). The collected leachate was stored in a zero headspace plastic bottle in a refrigerator at 4 °C until use. The average composition of the landfill leachate was as follows: pH 8.5; alkalinity, 4885 mg L−1 CaCO3; COD, 1254 mg L−1;
Cl
−
, 1270 mg L−1;
NO
3
−
, 0 mg L−1; and
SO
4
2 −
, 0 mg L−1. All chemicals were at least analytical grade, except as noted. In the experiments to test the effects of acids, pH was adjusted by concentrated nitric acid (HNO3, 70%; FishChemical, Fair Lawn, NJ, USA), sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 96%, FishChemical), and hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37%, FishChemical), respectively. In all the other tests, the initial pH was adjusted to the desired value with HNO3. If needed, potassium nitrate (NaNO3, 99%, Mallinckrodt, Paris, KY, USA), potassium sulfate (Na2SO4, 99%, FishChemical), and potassium chloride (KCl, 99%, FishChemical) were added to increase
NO
3
−
,
SO
4
2 −
, and
Cl
−
to the desirable levels, respectively. To prepare a leachate at 0 mg L−1
Cl
−
, silver nitrate (AgNO3, 99%, Alfa Aesar, Ward Hill, MA), at the same molar concentration as
Cl
−
originally in leacahte, was added to react with all
Cl
−
to form solid AgCl. After 1 day AgCl precipitation, the upper clean leachate without
Cl
−
was used. In a typical run, 20 mL leachate was dispensed to a 60 mL serum vial installed in a water bath shaker (Precision, reciprocal shaking bath model 50) at a controlled temperature of 25°C. Ferrous sulfate (FeSO4·7H2O, FishChemical) was added, followed by addition of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 30% w/w, VWR, West Chester, PA, USA). Once the Fenton oxidation was initiated, the shaker was turned on at 150 rpm to thoroughly stir the solution. After 30 min, the shaking was stopped, and the water bath temperature was increased to 50°C to accelerate self-decomposition of the residual H2O2. The leachate was heated for 30 min, and then 2 mL uniformly mixed solution was collected for COD analysis. Sample pH was measured by pH meter (Orion, Model 720). COD was measured colorimetrically (20–1500 mg L−1; HACH, Loveland, CO, USA). All experiments were run in duplicate. The error bars in the figures represent one standard deviation.

sec.title: Effects of the acids used for pH adjustment
sec.p:
As the equivalent weight ratio of H2O2 to O2 is 2.125, the mass ratio of 2.125H2O2 to initial COD (COD0) was used to indicate the H2O2 dose in this study. For example, when 2.125H2O2:COD0 = 2, the added H2O2 dose is twice as the dose that theoretically just oxidizes all the COD, although the actual COD removal is usually below 100% (Deng and Englehardt, 2006; Deng, 2007). The optimal experimental conditions for Fenton treatment of the leachate were as follows: pH 3, [H2O2]:[Fe2+] = 3, and 2.125H2O2:COD0 = 5. The method used to optimize Fenton oxidation is available elsewhere (Deng, 2007). Given that
NO
3
−
,
SO
4
2 −
, and
Cl
−
may be introduced from the acid for pH adjustment, the acid with the least inhibiting effect on Fenton oxidation should be determined. Three strong acids, HNO3, H2SO4, and HCl, were used to lower the pH of the leachate to 3.0, respectively. After pH adjustment, the
NO
3
−
,
SO
4
2 −
, and
Cl
−
concentrations were as follows (excluding 1616 mg L−1
SO
4
2 −
introduced from FeSO4·7H2O): for HNO3 adjustment, 6118 mg L−1
NO
3
−
, 0 mg L−1
SO
4
2 −
, and 1270 mg L−1
Cl
−
; for H2SO4 adjustment, 0 mg L−1
NO
3
−
, 4737 mg L−1
SO
4
2 −
, and 1270 mg L−1
Cl
−
; and for H2SO4 adjustment, 0 mg L−1
NO
3
−
, 0 mg L−1
SO
4
2 −
, and 4773 mg L−1
Cl
−
. For all the leachate samples, 99% of the acid used was to eliminate alkalinity, and 1% was used to lower pH from 4.5 to 3.0. The effects of the acids are shown in Figure 1. The highest COD removal of 56% was achieved at the samples adjusted by HNO3, followed by 49% at the H2SO4 group and then by 37% at the HCl group. HNO3 was the acid with the least negative impact on Fenton oxidation of the leachate. Therefore, HNO3 was be used for pH adjustment in the following tests.

caption.p: COD removal vs. various acids for pH adjustment (Conditions: 2.125H2O2:COD0 = 5; [H2O2]:[Fe2+] = 3; pH = 3.0).

sec.title: Effect of NO−3 and SO2−4
sec.p:
The effect of
NO
3
−
on COD removal is shown in Figure 2. COD removal dropped a little from 56 to 53% as the
NO
3
−
level increased from 6118 mg L−1 (introduced from HNO3 adjustment) to 50 000 mg L−1
NO
3
−
. Significant change in COD removal was not observed over the entire
NO
3
−
range. Thus,
NO
3
−
appeared not to considerably influence the oxidation efficiency of Fenton treatment. The effect of
SO
4
2 −
on COD removal is shown in Figure 3. COD removal decreased from 56 to 41% when the
SO
4
2 −
level was increased from 0 to 10 000 mg L−1. Therefore, sulfate slightly inhibited COD removal in Fenton treatment of leachate.

caption.p: Effect of (NO−3 ) on COD removal (Conditions: 2.125H2O2:COD0 = 5; [H2O2]:[Fe2+] = 3; pH = 3.0).
Effect of SO2−4 on COD removal (Conditions: 2.125H2O2:COD0 = 5; [H2O2]:[Fe2+] = 3; pH = 3.0; the additional 1616 mg L−1 SO2−4 is not included in the SO2−4 concentration).

sec.title: Effect of Cl−
sec.p:
The effect of
Cl
−
on COD removal is shown in Figure 4. It should be noted that 34% of COD in leachate was removed via adsorption to the precipitate in the preparation of 0 mg L−1
Cl
−
leachate. For any particular
Cl
−
level (0–10 000 mg L−1), COD removal increased with the increasing H2O2 dose. When 2.125H2O2:COD0 = 9.0, the COD removal efficiencies for the
Cl
−
levels of 0, 1270, 5000 and 10 000 mg L−1 were 96, 62, 49 and 37%, respectively.

caption.p: Effect of Cl− on COD removal (Conditions: [H2O2]:[Fe2+] = 3; pH = 3.0).

sec.p:
The
Cl
−
effect on the overall mass ratio of averaged H2O2 consumed to COD removed by Fenton oxidation is shown in Figure 5. It should be emphasized that COD removed by AgCl precipitate was excluded in the groups with 0 mg L−1
Cl
−
in Figure 5. For any particular
Cl
−
level, H2O2 consumption per unit mass of COD increased with the increasing H2O2 dose, implying that the increase in the H2O2 dose lowered its utilization efficiency. At a fixed H2O2 dose, no significant difference in the ratio was observed between 0 and 1270 mg L−1
Cl
−
groups, but the leachates with 5000 and 10 000 mg L−1 had much higher ratios of H2O2 consumption to COD oxidation, indicating that more H2O2 is required at a very high
Cl
−
concentration to complete the oxidation. For example, at 2.125H2O2:COD0 = 5, removal of 1 mg L−1 COD by oxidation at 0 and 10 000 mg L−1
Cl
−
needed 13.2 and 44.7 mg L−1 H2O2, respectively. The results showed that
Cl
−
significantly inhibited COD removal in Fenton oxidation of leachate, and the inhibiting effect increased with the increase in the
Cl
−
level.

caption.p: Effect of Cl− on overall mass ratio of H2O2 to COD removed by oxidation (Conditions: [H2O2]:[Fe2+] = 3; pH = 3.0; COD removal at 0 mg L−1 Cl− is the COD removal by Fenton oxidation, excluding COD removal by AgCl precipitation).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
In our study,
NO
3
−
,
SO
4
2 −
, and
Cl
−
exhibited different inhibiting behaviours in Fenton treatment of a landfill leachate.
NO
3
−
had no obvious impact on the reduction of organic species in leachate, because it neither complexes with Fe(II) or Fe(III) noticeably, nor does it scavenge OH· (Pignatello et al., 2007). Both
SO
4
2 −
and
Cl
−
hindered the COD removal. Particularly, the latter exhibited a significant inhibiting effect, and the inhibition degree was appreciably increased with the increasing
Cl
−
concentration. Primary reactions involved in
Cl
−
occurring in the Fenton system are listed in Table 3 below. The
Cl
−
effect on Fenton oxidation is probably ascribed to two reasons. First,
Cl
−
competes with organic species in leachate for OH·, to form less reactive chloride radicals that may continue to scavenge OH·. Hydroxyl radicals can be scavenged by
Cl
−
to form
ClOH
· −
(k19 = 4.3 × 109 M−1 s−1, the forward reaction of Eq. 19). The generated
ClOH
· −
can be further dissociated back to OH· and
Cl
−
k–19 = 6.1 × 109 M−1 s−1, the reverse reaction of Eq. 19). Furthermore,
ClOH
· −
reacts with hydrogen ion (H+) to form chloride atoms
( Cl
·
)
via a protonation reaction (Eq. 20). The reverse reaction rate constant of this protonation reaction (k–20 = 1.3 × 103 M−1 s−1) is much lower than the forward reaction rate constant (k20 = 2.1 × 1010 M−1 s−1). Given that the equilibrium constant in Eq. 20 is 1.6 × 107, almost 100% of chloride in Eq. 20 exists in the form of
Cl
·
, and thus very little
ClOH
· −
dissociates back to OH· via the reverse reaction of Eq. 19. Furthermore, the generated
Cl
·
can combine with
Cl
−
to form dichloride radicals
( Cl
2
· −
)
(Eq. 21). At pH ≥ 3 and
Cl
−
≥ 355 mg L−1, the
Cl
2
· −
can account for >99% of total radicals (De Laat and Le 2006). Despite their high redox potentials (Eo for
Cl
·
/
Cl
−
= 2.41 V and Eo for
Cl
2
· −
/2
Cl
−
= 2.09 V),
Cl
·
and
Cl
2
· −
are less reactive with organic species (Eq. 24 and 25) when compared with OH· (Pignatello, 1992; Lopes et al., 2002). For example,
Cl
2
· −
, the major radicals in the system, react with most of organic solutes at second-order rate constants of the order of 103–1010 M−1 s−1, which was lower than those in the reactions between OH· and organics (107–1010 M−1 s−1) (Buxton et al., 1988). Moreover,
Cl
·
and
Cl
2
· −
can rapidly consume H2O2 (Eq. 22 and 23), to decrease the OH· production via Fenton reaction. Additionally,
Cl
2
· −
degraded organic species preferentially through hydrogen abstraction, a less effective degradation pathway when organic materials are more highly oxidized. Therefore, the chloride radicals are very ineffective for COD reduction at the final stage of Fenton oxidation (Machulek et al., 2007).

Second, the
Cl
−
complexes iron ions to affect the distribution and reactivity of iron species. Chlorides compete with H2O2 to form Fe(III)-chlorocomplexes (Eq. 27–28), leading to re-distribution of iron species and reduction in their reactivity. As mentioned above, the reactions occurring in the Fenton system include two stages: first, Fe(II) is rapidly oxidized by H2O2 to produce Fe(III) and OH· (Eq. 4–5); second, H2O2 slowly reduces Fe(III) back to Fe(II) (Eq. 6–7), to reinitiate Fenton reaction and produce more OH·. Of note,
Cl
−
does not alter the OH· production rate in the first stage (Eq. 29), because the Fe(II) chlorocomplex (FeCl+) is characterized by the same reactivity of the free Fe(II) for the H2O2 decomposition and OH· production (Le Truong et al., 2004). In the second stage, when
Cl
−
is absent, H2O2 first reacts with Fe(III) to form at least two ferric hydroperoxocomplexes, Fe(OH2)2+ and Fe(OH)(HO2)+, which subsequently decompose to yield Fe(II) with k = 2.3 × 10−3 (Eq. 6–9). However, once added,
Cl
−
complexes with Fe(III) to form ferric-chlorocomplexes (FeCl2+ and
FeCl
2
+
) (Eq. 27–28). Since the equilibrium constants for formation of ferric chlorocomplexes (K for FeCl2+ = 6.6, K for
FeCl
2
+
= 10.5 in Table 2) are higher than K values for formation of hydroperoxocomplexes (K for Fe(OH2)2+ = 3.1 × 10−3, K for Fe(OH)(HO2)+ = 2.0 × 10−4) by three to four orders of magnitude, the ferric chlorocomplexes are dominant in an acidic solution with a high chloride concentration. For example, FeCl2+ and
FeCl
2
+
were reported to be the predominant Fe(III) species at pH = 1.3 and [
Cl
−
] > 200 mM (De Laat and Le, 2006). These iron-chlorocomplexes do not complex with H2O2, so that the important Fe(II) regeneration route from Fe(III) reduction is blocked, thus regenerating less OH·.

caption.p: Primary reactions involved in Cl− occurring in Fenton system (data taken from Jayson et al., 1973, Le Truong et al., 2004, De Laat and Le 2006)

tr.td: Reactions involving re-distribution of iron species due to the presence of chlorides

sec.p:
Similar to
Cl
−
,
SO
4
2 −
may affect Fenton oxidation of organic species through the scavenging of OH· and formation of unreactive iron-sulfato
( SO
4
· −
)
complexes via coordination. Primary reactions involving
SO
4
2 −
occurring in Fenton system are listed in Table 3.
SO
4
2 −
is a relatively poor OH· scavenger when compared with
Cl
−
, but the fraction of sulfate radicals in Fenton system is increased with the increasing
SO
4
2 −
concentration. Therefore, the effect of
SO
4
2 −
should not be ignored at a high
SO
4
2 −
level. For example, Le Truong et al., (2004) reported that the calculated dominant radicals switched from OH· to sulfate radicals at pH 2 and total inorganic radicals = 10−10 M, when
[ SO
4
2 −
]
> 100 mM. Sulfate radicals are much less reactive than OH·in terms of oxidation of organic matters (Liang and Su, 2009). On the other side, sulfate can also complex Fe(II) and Fe(III) to form Fe(II)- and Fe(III)- sulfato complexes, respectively (Eq. 35–37). Fe(II)-sulfato complexes (FeSO4) can decompose H2O2 (k39 = 78 M−1 s−1) to produce OH· more rapidly than free Fe(II) (k4 = 55 M−1 s−1). However, sulfate, like chloride, competes with H2O2 to complex Fe(III) to form Fe(III)-sulfato complexes (
FeSO
4
+
and
Fe ( SO 4 )
2
−
). These complexes do not coordinate with H2O2, and thus much less Fe(II) is regenerated through Fe(III) reduction by H2O2 (Pignatello et al., 2007). As a result, less OH· is produced in the second stage.

caption.p: Primary reactions involved in SO2−4 occurring in Fenton system (Le Truong et al., 2004)

tr.td: Reactions involving re-distribution of iron species due to the presence of sulfates

sec.p:
In Figure 5, the ratio of overall H2O2 consumption to COD oxidation exhibited a similar pattern for 0 mg L−1 and 1270 mg L−1
Cl
−
at different H2O2 doses. Moreover, after 34% COD removal by AgCl precipitation is excluded, 62% of COD removal due to oxidation is achieved for the 0 mg L−1
Cl
−
leachate at 2.125H2O2:COD0 = 9, very close to 63% of COD removal for 1270 mg L−1
Cl
−
leachate at the same H2O2 dose. However, the COD removal behaviours at the both
Cl
−
concentrations are different. With the increase in the COD removal efficiency, the amount of remaining organic species in leachate declined, and thus the
Cl
−
level relative to COD was increased. Consequently, the scavenging effect of
Cl
−
was enhanced. That is, in the presence of
Cl
−
, the Fenton oxidation would become more ineffective with the increase in COD removal. To examine the hypothesis, we doubled the doses of Fenton reagents (2.125H2O2: COD0 = 18, [H2O2]:[Fe2+] = 3) to treat the leachate at 1270 mg L−1
Cl
−
, and found that the COD removal was only increased to 79%. In fact, the COD removal curve for the leachate at 1270 mg L−1
Cl
−
is a representative one in Fenton treatment of landfill leachate, in agreement with the many previous findings (Lau et al., 2002; Lopez et al., 2004; Zhang et al., 2005, 2006; Batarseh et al., 2007; Deng, 2007), with the following trend: with the increase in doses of Fenton reagents, COD removal efficiency initially increases dramatically, and then rises slowly or even reaches a plateau. Apart from the effect of
Cl
−
, another possible explanation is that the highly oxidized organic species in leachate, after high COD removal is accomplished, are more recalcitrant to OH·-induced oxidation. Nevertheless, this is not true in this study, because COD removal increased almost linearly up to 96% with the increase of H2O2 dose for the leachate at 0 mg L−1
Cl
−
(Figure 5).

The study highlights the significant inhibiting effect of
Cl
−
on Fenton oxidation of leachate. Therefore, a much higher COD removal efficiency is expected if an appropriate treatment totally or largely removes
Cl
−
prior to Fenton oxidation. Although removal of
Cl
−
in leachate, a conservative species, is very difficult and expensive, several recent studies (Abdel-Wahab et al., 2005; Abdel-Wahab and Batchelor, 2006a, b, 2007) have provided promising results. For example, a recently developed advanced lime–aluminium softening process allows formation of layered double hydroxide solid phases for removal of
Cl
−
in addition to
SO
4
2 −
from water (Abdel-Wahab and Batchelor, 2006b).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
This study demonstrated the effects of various inorganic anions, originally present in or externally added to landfill leachate, on Fenton oxidation of leachate.
NO
3
−
did not have a significant impact on the COD removal rate. In contrast,
SO
4
2 −
and
Cl
−
, to different degrees, hindered Fenton oxidation. Particularly, the inhibiting effect of
Cl
−
was significant at a typical level for a landfill leachate. The negative effects of
SO
4
2 −
and
Cl
−
may be ascribed to: (1) scavenging of OH·; and (2) competition with H2O2 to form Fe(III) complexes, thus preventing the Fe(II) regeneration from Fe(III) reduction. As a result, Fenton oxidation typically achieves a moderate COD removal efficiency, incomparable to other chemical oxidation methods such as electrical-oxidation. When
Cl
−
was completely removed from the leachate, Fenton oxidation could reach an almost 100% COD removal rate at the moderate doses of Fenton reagents. The results again proved the role of
Cl
−
in slowing down Fenton oxidation.

ref.citation: Abdel-WahabA BatchelorB SchwantesJ (2005) An equilibrium model for chloride removal from recycled cooling water using the ultra-high lime with aluminum process. Water Environmental Research 77: 3059–3065.
Abdel-WahabA BatchelorB (2006a) Effects of pH, temperature, and water quality on chloride removal with ultra-high lime with aluminum process. Water Environmental Research 78: 930–937.
Abdel-WahabA BatchelorB (2006b) Interactions between chloride and sulfate or silica removals using an advanced lime-aluminum softening process. Water Environmental Research 78: 2474–2479.

Abdel-WahabA BatchelorB (2007) Interactions between chloride and sulfate or silica removals from wastewater using an advanced lime-aluminum softening process: Equilibrium modeling. Water Environmental Research 79: 528–535.
BarbWG BaxendaleJH GeorgeP HargraveKR (1951) Reactions of ferrous and ferric ions with hydrogen peroxide. Part I. The ferrous ion reaction. Transactions of the Faraday Society 47: 462–500.
BatarsehES ReinhartDR DalyL (2007) Liquid sodium ferrate and Fenton’s reagent for treatment of mature landfill leachate. Journal of Enviornmental Engineering 133: 1042–1050.

BuxtonGV GreenstockCL HelmanWP RossAB (1988) Critical review of rate constants for reactions of hydrated electrons, hydrogen-atoms and hydroxyl radicals (.OH/.O−) in aqueous-solution. Journal of Physical and Chemical Reference Data 17: 513–886.
De LaatJ GallardH (1999) Catalytic decomposition of hydrogen peroxide by Fe(III) in homogeneous aqueous solution: Mechanism and kinetic modeling. Environmental Science & Technology 33: 2726–2732.
